hadiths.english_translation: Abdullah ibn Muhammad al-Sha'bani reported: Some scholars from Sha'ban told us, among them Muhammad ibn Abi Umayyah, a learned man, that when rain fell on Yemen, a flood exposed a vault with a stone door. When the lock was broken and they entered, there was a large hall with a golden bed on which lay a man. When they measured him, his height was twelve spans. He wore ornate garments woven with gold. Next to him was a golden staff with a red ruby on its head. The man was white-headed and bearded with two long locks of hair. Next to him was a tablet inscribed in Himyarite script: 'By Your name, O Allah, Lord of Himyar. I am Hassan ibn Amr al-Qil, when there is no lord but Allah. I lived with hope and died with an appointed term. In the days of Wakhz Hehid, and what is Wakhz Hehid? Twelve thousand chiefs perished in it, and I was their last to be killed. I came to the mountain of Dhu al-Shi'abayn to protect me from death, but it failed me.' Next to him was a sword inscribed in Himyarite: 'I am Qubar, by me vengeance is obtained.'

hadiths.english_translation: Abdullah ibn Idris reported: I heard Laythi mentioning that al-Sha'bi said: I stayed in Madinah with Abdullah ibn Umar for eight or ten months. Muhammad ibn Sa'd said: The reason for his stay in Madinah was that he feared al-Mukhtar, so he fled from him to Madinah and remained there.

hadiths.english_translation: Ubaidullah ibn Musa reported: Isra'il narrated to us from Isa ibn Abi Azza, who said: I stayed with Amir (al-Sha'bi) in Khurasan for ten months, and he would not exceed two rak'ahs (in prayer). Muhammad ibn Sa'd said: He had an administrative office and used to lead raids on it. He was a Shi'ite and witnessed certain matters from them and heard their discourse and their extremism, so he abandoned their views and used to criticize them.
